attributes.title: Konsep Sekolah Efektif Dan Proses Perbaikan Mutu Pendidikan Di Indonesia

summary.value: Keunggulan suatu bangsa tidak lagi bertumpu pada kekayaan alam, melainkan pada keunggulan sumber daya manusia (SDM), yaitu tenaga terdidik yang mampu menjawab tantangan-tantangan yang sangat cepat. Kenyataan ini sudah lebih dari cukup untuk mendorong pakar dan praktisi pendidikan melakukan kajian sistematik untuk membenahi atau memperbaiki sistem pendidikan nasional. Agar keluaran sekolah mampu beradaptasi secara dinamis dengan perubahan dan tantangan itu, pemerintah melontarkan gagasan tentang manajemen pendidikan yang berbasis sekolah (school-based management) yang memberikan ruang yang luas bagi sekolah dan masyarakatnya untuk menentukan program dan rencana pengembangan diri sesuai dengan kebutuhan dan kondisi masing-masing. Efektifitas sekolah menunjukan adanya proses perekayasaan berbagai sumber dan metode yang diarahkan pada terjadinya pembelajaran disekolah secara optimal. Efektifitas sekolah merujuk pada pemberdayaan semua komponen sekolah sebagai organisasi tempat belajar berdasarkan tugas pokok dan fungsinya masing-masing dalam struktur program dengan tujuan agar siswa belajar dan mencapai hasil yang telah ditetapkan, yaitu memiliki kompetensi. Pada sekolah efektif, semua siswa baik siswa yang mempunyai kemampuan tinggi dalam belajar, yang dapat mengembangkan diri, siswa yang memiliki kemampuan intelektualitas yang biasapun dapat mengembangkan dirinya, jika dibandingkan dengan	kondisi	awal	ketika	mereka	baru	memasuki	sekolah. Jadi konsep sekolah efektif adalah sekolah yang mampu mengoptimalkan semua masukan dan proses bagi ketercapaian output pendidikan, yaitu prestasi sekolah terutama prestasi siswa yang ditandai dengan dimilikinya semua kemampuan berupa kompetensi yang dipersyaratkan didalam belajar.

attributes.title: UniSiegenExP2020 - G4A Package Leaflet and Motivation

q1.value: Impact of pictrograms on the current motivation to read

q2.value: Emma Höfer, Annika Alina Buchholz, Julia Haberstroh, Sophie Seeger, Philipp Timpe

q3.value:
This is a project by psychology students as part of a course of the University of Siegen, Germany.

Until now numerous studies have focused on how package leaflets could be improved with regard to readability and understanding of the presented information but none focused on how to increase the motivation of reading a package leaflet first. Therefore, we will measure current motivation for the standard version of a package leaflet and for a package leaflet with pictograms.

q4.value: The motivation of reading a package leaflet increases with symbols and pictograms shown in the package leaflet in comparison to a package leaflet without symbols and pictograms.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study design is a cross over, within-subject design, so that each participant goes through both conditions. The conditions are (1) a package leaflet of pain mediaction with pictograms (Ibuprofen Schmerztabletten 400 mg) and (2) a package leaflet of pain medication without pictograms (Ibuprofen Schmerztabletten 400 mg). Participants will be allocated to one of the conditions by simple randomization. This is a design with 1 factor (presentation form) and 2 levels (with pictograms, without pictograms).

q9.value:
In the first step participants will be allocated to one of the conditions by simple randomization. Blocks are not needed because each participant will go through both conditions. 

Example: 
Group A: package leaflet (1), package leaflet (2)
Group B: package leaflet (2), package leaflet (1)

The randomization will be conducted via the online survey application "LimeSurvey".

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth recommendation. Participants will not be paid but psychology students that participated will receive a certificate after the trial which is useful for completing the bachelors degree. Participants must be aged from 19 to 65 years. Furthermore person who have a reading/spelling disorder, severe neuronal disorders or forms of analphabetism are excluded.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 45 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 60 participants, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a great effect size of .656 at .01 alpha error probability.

q15.value: The data collection procedures will end on 31th march 2020. The limit of pariticipants is 60.

question.value:
We manipulate the presentation of medical informations (independent variable) by adding symbols and pictograms to a package leaflet of pain medication (Ibuprofen Schmerztabletten 400 mg) in comparison to the standard package leaflet of pain medication (Ibuprofen Schmerztabletten 400 mg) without symbols and pictograms. The dependent variable is the motivation of reading a package leaflet.

The order of the presentation (with, with-out) also will be manipulated, because at the beginning each participant will be allocated by randomization to one of the conditions .

We want to measure the current motivation of reading by a questionnaire of 18 items, where we ask on a scale of 1-7 wether the message is not correct (1) or correct (7). The 18 items are divided in to 4 subscales: challenge, Interest and probability of success, fear of failure. The subscale challenge is defined by items 6,8,10,15. The subscale interest is defined by items 1,4,7,11,17. The subscale probability of success is defined by items 2,3,13,14. The last subscale fear of failure is definded by items 5,9,12,16,18.
For this we use a modified form of the "FAM- Fragebogen zur aktuellen Motivation" by Rheinberg and Vollmeyer. Our modification is inspired by the "Motivation for Reading" by Wigfild and Baker.

Furthermore we will collect information about the age of participants in the subscale "age" that will be separated in two groups: (1) under the age of 30, (2) over the age of 30.

We will take the mean of both groups: package leaflets with and without pictograms. 

We will take also the mean of the both age groups under and over the age of 30.

The mean of the presentation order groups is also will be taken: A:(1) package leaflet with pictures, then (2) package leaflet without pictures OR B:(2) package leaflet without pictures, then (1) package leaflet with pictures

We will use a t-test to find out the difference between the two dependent means of the package leaflet manipulation condition. 

We will also use a t-test to do an analysis of the subscale "age" to find out differences between the means of different age groups.

An analysis of the difference between the presentation order (first group A or B) by using a t-test is also planned.

q21.value: We will use p; .01 and power .95 and a two tailed test.

q22.value: Data will be excluded if the subject did not answer both questionnaires.

q25.value:
Our study is based on the models of  "current motivation" (Rheinberg, 2004c) and "reading motivation" (Möller and Schiefele, 2004).
Studies we are referring to: 

1. "How Representational Pictures Enhance Students’ Performance and Test-Taking Pleasure in Low-Stakes Assessment" by Marlit A. Lindner, Jan M. Ihme, Steffani Saß, and Olaf Köller.

2. "COMPREHENSIBILITY OF THE PACKAGE LEAFLETS OF ALL MEDICINAL PRODUCTS FOR HUMAN USE: A QUESTIONNAIRE SURVEY ABOUT THE USE OF SYMBOLS AND PICTOGRAMS"
CLAUDIA BERNARDINIU, VALERIA AMBROGI, LUANA PERIOLI, MARIA CRISTINA TIRALTI and GIUSEPPE FARDELLA

3. "FAM: Ein Fragebogen zur Erfassung aktueller Motivation in Lern- und Leistungssituationen"
(Langversion, 2001) by Falko Rheinberg, Regina Vollmeyer and Bruce D. Burns.

4. "Dimensions of Children’s Motivation for Reading and Their Relations to Reading Activity and Reading Achievement" b Linda Baker and Allan Wigfield 

5. Improving Comprehension in Written Medical Informed Consent Procedures by Schatz et al. (2017)

q1.value: Effects of Teacher Implemented Schema-Based Instruction

q2.value: Corey Peltier, Emily Kuntz, Tiffany K Peltier, Heather Eisel

q3.value: Schema-Based instruction (SBI) has been shown to be an effective intervention to promote the mathematical problem solving performance of students with and without disabilities. However, replication studies are needed to demonstrate whether effects are maintained when using a natural change agent (e.g., teachers). The goal of our study was to investigate the effects of SBI on the mathematical problem solving performance of students with disabilities when implemented by a special education teacher. We collected multiple dependent variables on the teacher (i.e., the fidelity of implementation, opportunities to respond [OTR], behavior specific praise [BSP]) to investigate how external features of implementation may affect results. Second, in addition to evaluating students' problem solving performance, we collected data on their on-task behavior and disruptive behavior to identify whether responsiveness to intervention may be correlated with behavior.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that students with lower levels of on-task behavior will receive lesser effects from the intervention.

We hypothesize that students with more disruptive behavior will correlate with lower levels of fidelity for the teacher and lower levels of behavior specific praise.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will use a multiple-baseline design across students. We anticipated including three students in the experiment; however if more consent we will include them in groups in the design.

q9.value: We will include two types of randomization in this experiment. First, we will randomize the start point for each case. We will use a randomization procedure without replacement (i.e., session 6 through 12). In addition, we will then randomize participants to each "case."

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The following inclusion criteria will be applied: (a) students are receiving special education instruction in an elementary resource room instruction and (b) participants are identified with deficits in mathematics.

q13.value: We aim to recruit all of the students receiving special education instruction from this resource room teacher who has an identified deficits in mathematics. The minimum number of students we need to recruit to establish a functional relation is three students.

q14.value: In a multiple-baseline design, three changes at three different points of time is the bare minimum to establish a functional relation between the independent variable and the dependent variable. Thus, we need a bare minimum of three participants.

q15.value: We plan to terminate data collection five weeks post-intervention for each case. This time frame may infringe upon end-of-year high-stakes assessments, but that is our goal.

question.value:
The independent variable the teacher will implement is schema-based instruction (see Powell, 2011).

We will collect three dependent variables on the teacher's behavior. The first dependent variable will be fidelity of implementation. To evaluate fidelity we will use a procedural checklist and a qualitative component for each step. The second dependent variable we will collect is opportunities to respond. The third dependent variable we will collect is behavior specific praise statements provided per minute.

We will collect three dependent variables on the students' behavior. The primary dependent variable will be problem solving performance, which will be evaluated through a checklist. The second dependent variable will be on-task behavior. The third dependent variable will be disruptive behavior.

Teacher fidelity will be evaluated using a procedural checklist that includes a Likert scale component (0 = not present, 1 = present, 2 = presented with quality). Teacher's provision of opportunities to respond will be defined as a gestural or vocal prompt for the student to respond either vocally or physically. We will calculate the rate of OTRs per minute. Teacher's provision of behavior specific praise will be defined as a praise statement with an explicit reference to a behavior. An example consists of "Jimmy, great job identifying the structure of the problem," a non-example includes "Good job Jimmy." We will calculate the rate of behavior specific praise statements per minute.

Student problem solving performance will be evaluated through a rubric (1 point = draw correct structure, 1 point = fill in quantities into correct spot, 1 point = number sentence that will faciliate solution, 1 point = correct solution calculated). Each problem will be evaluated in isolation and scores will be summed to report an overall score per probe sheet.

Student on-task behavior is defined as eyes on the teacher, vocally responding to teacher prompts, and use of materials as defined by teacher. On-task behavior will be measured through whole interval recording, intervals will be defined as 5 second intervals.

Student disruptive behavior is defined as physical or verbal behavior that is not related to a teacher prompt. Disruptive behavior will be measured through partial interval recording, intervals will be defined as 5 second intervals.

Our first step will be to create a graphical display of the data that fits predetermined specifications (Y:X ratio between 5:8 and 2:3 and DPPXYR [see Radley et al., 2018] 0.14–0.16). Second, we will adhere to the What Works Clearinghouse Guidelines for engaging in visual analysis to determine a functional relation. Third, we will compute two effect size indices to estimate the magnitude of change: Tau and the Between-Case Standardized Mean Difference (BC-SMD). Last, we will conduct single-case randomization tests using Gafurov and Levin's (2018) ExPRT program to conduct null hypothesis tests to determine if the mean level change between baseline and intervention were statistically significantly different.

q21.value: For the single-case randomization tests, we will set the alpha level at 0.05.

q22.value: We will not exclude any data, or drop any cases –unless a student or familye revokes their consent.

q23.value: If a student misses a probe session we will have the teacher administer the probe sheet the next day the student is present. We will identify that the datum reflects a different data of administration on the graph.

sample.value: Based on a power analysis using G*Power, our goal is to recruit 300 non-Black-White participants (50% Black, 50% White).

analyses.value:
We will run two linear regressions. Both will have as predictor variables essentialism and participant race (White/Black), as covariates SDO, racial prejudice, need for cognitive closure, political attitudes, participant age and education, and as the dependent variables: 1) perceived representativeness and 2) willingness to vote. 

1) Predictor variables (Essentialism, Participant Race (White/Black), Covariates: SDO,

outliers.value: Participants who do not complete the entire survey will be excluded, as will those who do not self-identify as Black or White.

dependent.value:
1) How representative of the Black-White community is a person who identifies as a mixture of Black and White.

2) Willingness to vote for a person who identifies as a mixture of Black and White to lead a multiracial organization.

hypothesis.value: Does essentialism increase the likelihood of voting for a Black-White individual who self-identifies as a mixture of Black and White to lead a multiracial organization.

attributes.title: The Relation between Narcissism and Aggression: A Meta-Analysis

q1.value: The Relation between Narcissism and Aggression: A Meta-Analysis

q3.value:
Due to the hostility and lack of empathy that individuals with narcissism often display, narcissism is often linked to aggressive behaviors. Both proactive and reactive aggression have been associated with narcissism: proactive aggression refers to goal-oriented aggressive behaviors that are purposeful, and reactive aggression refers to aggressive behaviors that occur as a result of provocation such as verbal insult or physical attack (Fossati, Borroni, Eisenberg & Maffei, 2010;  Walters, 2005; Vize et al., 2018). Although one meta-analysis has examined how narcissism associated with provoked aggression, narcissism, however, is not a homogeneous construct. Narcissism can be conceived at three levels: as a global construct, as two prototypical presentations (i.e. grandiosity and vulnerability), and as a trifurcated model with three underlying factors: interpersonal antagonism, neuroticism, and agentic extraversion (Crowe, Lynam, Campbell, & Miller, 2019). Most studies on narcissism and aggression conceptualized narcissism broadly as a global factor, and these studies showed that individuals with narcissism are likely to be aggression in both provoked and unprovoked condition (Bushman & Baumeister, 1998; Rasmussen, 2016; Reidy, Foster & Zeichner, 2010). More recent studies have found that when breaking down narcissism into its two variants, grandiose and vulnerable narcissism differ in their associations with proactive and reactive aggression. Grandiose narcissism was found to associate strongly with both types of aggression, and vulnerable narcissism was found to associate more strongly with reactive aggression than proactive aggression (Lobbestael et al., 2014; Vize et al., 2019a). Only one study has examined how narcissism associates with aggression at the three-factor level (Vize et al., 2019a), and results from the study showed that relative to Neuroticism and Agentic Extraversion, Interpersonal Antagonism appears to be the dominant predictor of both proactive and reactive aggression. Although the three narcissism factors may not be isomorphic to Neuroticism, Agreeableness, and Extraversion in the Five Factor Model (FFM), given the strong connection between the two models, results from another meta-analysis (Vize et al., 2019b) are relevant to our study: the authors examined the associations between the FFM and different types of aggression, and they found that though neuroticism is moderately related to reactive aggression, it is only weakly related to proactive aggression. In contrast, agreeableness is moderately to strongly related to both types of aggression. 
	Recurrent display of aggressive behaviors can seriously harm individuals’ social and psychological functioning. To further understand the association between narcissism and aggression, it is important to synthesize existing literature that studied both sets of variables. One meta-analysis has examined narcissism and aggression and found a significant positive association between them (Rasmussen, 2016). However, the analysis only accounted for provoked aggression and studied narcissism as a global factor, which makes it hard to conclude whether the effect can be generalized across all dimensions of narcissism and both types of aggressive behaviors. Thus, the goal of the proposed project is to conduct a meta-analysis to comprehensively examine the relation between three levels of narcissism (i.e. global factor, the dual-variant model, and the trifurcated model) and three forms of aggression (i.e. proactive, reactive, and general aggression) by decomposing the global relation between Narcissism and Aggression into subtypes of aggression and subcomponents of Narcissism using existing literature. 
Broad Guiding Question: To what extent does narcissism across its three levels relate to different types of trait aggression?
Sub-Questions:
1. To what extent does general narcissism, as a global factor, correlate with proactive, reactive, and general aggression?
2. To what extent do grandiose and vulnerable narcissism correlate with proactive, reactive, and general aggression?
3. To what extent do Interpersonal Antagonism, Neuroticism, and Agentic Extraversion correlate with proactive, reactive, and general aggression?

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: The global factor of narcissism will associate positively with proactive, reactive, and general aggression.
Hypothesis 2: Grandiose and vulnerable narcissism will both associate positively with proactive, reactive, and general aggression. Vulnerable narcissism will associate more strongly with reactive aggression than proactive aggression.
Hypothesis 3: At the trifurcated level, Interpersonal Antagonism will associate positive with proactive, reactive, and general aggression. Neuroticism will associate positively with reactive aggression. Agentic Extraversion is not expected to show significant association with any forms of aggression.

question.value: The proposed meta-analysis includes three components: 1) a meta-analysis on general narcissism as a predictor of trait aggression (i.e. proactive, reactive, and general aggression); 2) a moderator analysis that examines how the percentage of each of the two variant of narcissism (i.e. vulnerability and grandiosity) in the narcissism measures included in the other studies affect the association between narcissism and trait aggression.; 3) a moderator analysis that examines how the percentage of each of the trifurcated factors (i.e. Interpersonal Antagonism, Neuroticism and Agentic Extraversion) in the narcissism measures included in the other studies affect the association between narcissism and trait aggression.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Sources to Search
PubMed; PsycINFO; EBSCOhost; ProQuest Dissertations & Theses.
We will use these four databases ensure coverage of findings published in diverse fields and journals, while reducing possible redundancy. For search results without full-text availability online (e.g. unpublished dissertation), we will contact the authors to solicit full-text article. We will also examine previous reviews and meta-analyses for studies that meet our criteria.

Key words for searching in databases
(All Text: Narcissis* OR narcissistic personality disorder OR Narcissistic Personality Inventory OR Narcissistic Grandiosity Scale OR Grandiose Narcissism Scale OR Five‐Factor Narcissism Inventory OR Pathological Narcissism Inventory) AND (All Text: aggression OR violence OR antisocial OR crime OR delinquency OR offending)
Additional limits – Date: From 1999 to 2019; Language: English

Data Extraction
	The elected databases (PubMed; PsycINFO; EBSCOhost; ProQuest; see point 8 for more information) will be searched using the key terms and search strategy noted in point 9. Returned studies will be entered into an excel worksheet and duplicates will be removed. Following this, the first author will screen the data based on pre-specified inclusion and exclusion criteria (see points 13 and 14). In the first round of screening, we will screen articles based on titles, abstracts, and keywords to remove non-relevant articles. In the next step we will complete full-text searches to determine whether articles fulfill our inclusion criteria. After we identify a group of relevant studies, several variables will be extracted and formally coded. In addition to effect sizes (rs) between narcissism factors and trait aggression, we will code for relevant demographic data (mean age, percentage male, percentage White), sample size, sample type (student, community, clinical, forensic), source of information for narcissism and aggression (self-report, informant-report, clinician ratings, interview, official records, laboratory tasks), nature of the measured relation (concurrent vs. longitudinal), measure of narcissism (e.g., Narcissistic Personality Inventory, Pathological Narcissism Inventory), and measure of aggression (e.g., Reactive–Proactive Questionnaire). The first author will extract and record all the information, and to ensure the articles are coded reliably, an independent coder will record the same information for 20% of the articles in the meta-analysis. We will compare the independent coder’s results to the original coding from the first author. We will calculate intraclass correlations for effect size reliability and percent agreement for categorical moderators and sample characteristics (e.g. sample size). Any disagreement below .95 or 95% will be investigated to ensure the correct relations were used for the meta-analysis. To partially correct for the influence of measurement error, we will also code the reliability (e.g. Cronbach’s alpha) of the narcissism measures to calculate the disattenuated effect sizes. 

Inclusion criteria:
We will include studies that 
a) Have reported empirical research
b) Have included at least one measure of narcissism and one measure of aggression
c) Have reported statistics of the relation(s) between narcissism and trait aggression
d) Have collected data from adult sample
e) Have been published in the past two decades (i.e. from 1999 to 2019)
f) Have been published in English

Exclusion criteria:
We will exclude studies that 
a) Do not meet any of the inclusion criteria
b) Involved laboratory manipulation in aggression assessment
c) Used a sample that have already been used in another study

Anticipated Project Timeline:
The completion of this project is designed to fulfill the preliminary examination requirement of the primary author’s training program. The project has been approved by the preliminary examination committee on December 10th, 2019). Study collection and coding will take place from February to March 2020. Analyses will be run, and results will be summarized during April 2020, with the goal of defending the preliminary examination in May 2020. We expect to submit the study by June 2020.

Stage of Review at Completion of Pre-Registration:
Preliminary reading (COMPLETE)
Preliminary scoping & pilot search for studies (COMPLETE)
Study Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria and Design (COMPLETE)
Systematic Search & Screening (by March 2020)
Data Extraction (by March 2020)
Analysis of Data (by April 2020)
Project Write-Up (by May 2020)

q13.value: Our initial search in PSYCINFO using the search terms provided in this registration showed an initial result of 1353 studies. The final sample size (i.e. the number of studies included) is expected to be much smaller after taking out studies using our inclusion and exclusion criteria (see the previous section).

question.value:
Independent variables:
Our predictive variables are narcissism and its associated components, across all three levels of conceptualization (i.e. global factor, the dual-variant model, and the trifurcated model). We will include studies that measure at least one measure that assess narcissism as a continuous variable.

Dependent variables:
Our outcome variables are trait aggression and its associated subtypes (e.g. proactive and reactive). We will include studies that measure at least one measure that assess trait aggression as a continuous variable.

Potential Moderators:
a) Age (mean age)
b) Gender (percent male)
c) Ethnicity (percent White)
d) Sample type (student, community, clinical, forensic)
e) Source of information for both narcissism and aggression (self-report, informant-report, clinician ratings, interview, official records, laboratory tasks)
f) Nature of the measured relation (concurrent vs. longitudinal)
g) Measure of narcissism (e.g., Narcissistic Personality Inventory, Pathological Narcissism Inventory)
h) Measure of aggression (e.g., Reactive–Proactive Questionnaire)
i)  Percentage of vulnerability and grandiosity in the narcissism scales. (Relative weights analysis that examine the effect of each of the three components on aggression, details to follow in point 16)
j)  Percentage of Interpersonal Antagonism, Agentic Extraversion, and Neuroticism in the narcissism scales. (Relative weights analysis that examine the effect of each of the three components on aggression, details to follow in the data analysis section)
k) Features of narcissism measures, including test-retest reliability, targeting clinical/non-clinical population, and reading level, if possible
l) Features of aggression measures, including test-retest reliability, severity, physical/non-physical behaviors, and reading level, if possible
m) Sample’s country of origin

Computing mean effect sizes:
	Because narcissism and aggression are both assumed to be continuous, all effect sizes will be represented using the Pearson correlation coefficient (r). When correlation coefficients were not reported, r will be calculated either by converting existing parametric statistics (e.g. F, t, and d) or directly from means and standard deviations provided in the article. We will then generate mean effect sizes as well as their 95% confidence intervals for each relation of interest between narcissism and aggression. Multiple samples reported on in the same article will be treated as independent samples and will each be included in the analysis.
	Given the nonadditive nature of correlation coefficients, all effect sizes will first be transformed into z' units using the Fisher z' transformation (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001) before being averaged. To derive a mean effect size across samples, each effect size (ESi) will weighted by the inverse of its variance (wi). 
Specific approach for analyzing effects associated with the trifurcated model of narcissism
	An initial, informal review of the literature showed that most studies that assessed both narcissism and aggression studied narcissism at either the global factor level or the dual-variant level. Although it may not be possible to formally meta-analyze how the trifurcated model of narcissism relate to aggression, due to the hierarchical structure across different levels of narcissism (Crowe, Lynam, Campbell, & Miller, 2019), it is possible to infer the relation using known associations between the three factors and commonly used narcissism inventories. Relative weights (Tonidandel & LeBreton, 2015) of Interpersonal Antagonism, Agentic Extraversion, and Neuroticism in each of the commonly used narcissism measures will be extracted from existing studies (e.g. Crowe, Lynam, Campbell, & Miller, 2019), and these weights will be used to estimate how effect sizes of narcissism on aggression vary as a function of these relative weights across different measures of narcissism. We will run the moderator analysis using both raw weights and weight percentages from the relative weights analysis.

Evaluating differences in strengths of effect:
	To compare strengths of effect across different narcissism components or different forms of aggression, we will use  Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method (Lunn et al., 2000) to directly testing the likelihood of significant difference of the effects through simulation.

Heterogeneity in effect size:
	I2 statistics will be calculated and reported to examine overall heterogeneity that can be attributed to true between-studies variation (Higgins et al., 2003). 

Outlier identification:
	All effect sizes will be transformed to z' units and values of z' outside the range of –2.5 and 2.5 standard deviations will be considered outliers. We will report results with and without the outliers.

Publication Bias:
	We will use funnel plots to assess publication bias for each predictor. This method allows us to detect potential bias that are caused by underrepresentation of studies with small samples. When there is evidence of publication bias, we will use the trim and fill method (Duval and Tweedie, 2000) to estimate and impute potential missing studies.

Statistical software:
	Data will be analyzed using the “escalc”, “rma”, “funnel” and “trimfill” functions in the “metafor” R package.

Computing mean effect sizes:
	Because narcissism and aggression are both assumed to be continuous, all effect sizes will be represented using the Pearson correlation coefficient (r). When correlation coefficients were not reported, r will be calculated either by converting existing parametric statistics (e.g. F, t, and d) or directly from means and standard deviations provided in the article. We will then generate mean effect sizes as well as their 95% confidence intervals for each relation of interest between narcissism and aggression. Multiple samples reported on in the same article will be treated as independent samples and will each be included in the analysis.
	Given the nonadditive nature of correlation coefficients, all effect sizes will first be transformed into z' units using the Fisher z' transformation (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001) before being averaged. To derive a mean effect size across samples, each effect size (ESi) will weighted by the inverse of its variance (wi). 
Specific approach for analyzing effects associated with the trifurcated model of narcissism
	An initial, informal review of the literature showed that most studies that assessed both narcissism and aggression studied narcissism at either the global factor level or the dual-variant level. Although it may not be possible to formally meta-analyze how the trifurcated model of narcissism relate to aggression, due to the hierarchical structure across different levels of narcissism (Crowe, Lynam, Campbell, & Miller, 2019), it is possible to infer the relation using known associations between the three factors and commonly used narcissism inventories. Relative weights (Tonidandel & LeBreton, 2015) of Interpersonal Antagonism, Agentic Extraversion, and Neuroticism in each of the commonly used narcissism measures will be extracted from existing studies (e.g. Crowe, Lynam, Campbell, & Miller, 2019), and these weights will be used to estimate how effect sizes of narcissism on aggression vary as a function of these relative weights across different measures of narcissism. We will run the moderator analysis using both raw weights and weight percentages from the relative weights analysis.

Evaluating differences in strengths of effect:
	To compare strengths of effect across different narcissism components or different forms of aggression, we will use  Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method (Lunn et al., 2000) to directly testing the likelihood of significant difference of the effects through simulation.

Heterogeneity in effect size:
	I2 statistics will be calculated and reported to examine overall heterogeneity that can be attributed to true between-studies variation (Higgins et al., 2003). 

Outlier identification:
	All effect sizes will be transformed to z' units and values of z' outside the range of –2.5 and 2.5 standard deviations will be considered outliers. We will report results with and without the outliers.

Publication Bias:
	We will use funnel plots to assess publication bias for each predictor. This method allows us to detect potential bias that are caused by underrepresentation of studies with small samples. When there is evidence of publication bias, we will use the trim and fill method (Duval and Tweedie, 2000) to estimate and impute potential missing studies.

Statistical software:
	Data will be analyzed using the “escalc”, “rma”, “funnel” and “trimfill” functions in the “metafor” R package.

q3.value: This experiment examines the effect of self-referencing compared to other-referencing on true and false memories. It will use the Deese-Roediger-McDermott task. This experiment will also examine two methods of self-referencing to determine if either provides a stronger self-referencing effect.

q4.value:
We predict that: 
1) Encoding referent will affect recognition for presented words. Specifically, presented words in the self-referenced condition will be recognized more than words in the other-referenced condition
2) Encoding referent will affect recognition for critical lures. Specifically, critical lures in the self-referenced condition will be recognized more than critical lures in the other-referenced condition
3) We do not make any predictions about the two self-referencing tasks (the rating vs paired conditions).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: There are two independent variables: 1) encoding referent (self vs other) and encoding task (rating or paired). The first IV is within-subjects and the second is between-subjects. There are three dependent variables: proportion of presented words recognized, proportion of critical lures recognized, and proportion of foils recognized. From these data, we will compute net accuracy by dividing the proportion of presented words recognized by the sum of the proportion of presented words and critical lures recognized.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two encoding tasks (rating vs paired). The order of the 12 word lists will be randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data from psychology students at California State University San Marcos. They will receive credit toward the completion of a research requirement. All participants who complete the study will be included in the final sample. The study will begin in February 2020.

q14.value: We conducted a series of power analyses. First, to examine differences in critical lures recognition for the self- and other-referenced conditions, we based the power analysis on the results from Experiment 1. The effect size was d = .52, and a power analysis revealed that we need 32 participants to detect this effect. The effect for true memories was d = .18. Because we think the longer retention interval will remove ceiling effects and show a larger effect, we used the effect size d = .20. This resulted in the need for 199 participants. We will round up to 200 to have an even number in each between-subjects condition for the encoding task.

q15.value: We will collect data until we have 200 participants who have completed the study (100 in each between-subjects condition).

question.value: There is are two manipulated variables: 1) encoding referent, with two levels: self-referenced and other-referenced, and 2) encoding task, with two levels: rated or paired
We will measure recognition rates of presented words, critical lures, and foils. We will also measure symmetry span scores.
We will compute net accuracy by dividing the proportion of presented words recognized by the sum of the proportion of presented words and critical lures recognized.

We will run three two-way ANOVAs. Each ANOVA will have encoding referent and encoding task as independent factors. One will have recognition of presented words as the DV, one will have recognition of critical lures and the DV, and one will have net accuracy as the DV. 
We will also compare critical lure rates to foil rates in a set of t-tests (one for each condition).

q21.value: We will set alpha = .05 and reject null hypotheses in cases where p < alpha.

q22.value: We will only exclude participants who respond without variance (either all 'yes' or 'no' responses) in the recognition test.

q24.value: We will perform a few exploratory analyses. 1) we will explore how the valence of the word lists affect true and false memories. We have counterbalanced valence in each condition (half positive and half negative), and we will explore differences. 2) We will also explore differences between the two encoding tasks and how the task interacts with self- vs other-rating. 3) we will explore how symmetry span related to recognition rates for presented word, critical lures, and foils, for both self- and other-rated words.

attributes.title: Award Support Item - Headphones vs. Speakers

summary.value:
We have collected data from 66 participants thus far for a study we preregistered on As Predicted. We decided to add an additional dependent variable moving forward: 
"[Communicator] is being nominated for the UC San Diego Alumni Award for her work helping the blind! Would you like to write a few sentences to support [communicator] getting this award?" (Yes/No; if yes, participants have an option to write a few sentences of support). 

We predict that participants who listen to the clip in headphones (vs. speakers) will be more likely to write in support of the communicator receiving this award. 

Data collection will continue from today (February 13th) through February 21st. We hope to collect 100 participants with this new DV.

attributes.title: Does protest affect street-level bureaucrats’ behavior? The case of Black Lives Matter and policing

q1.value: Does protest affect street-level bureaucrats’ behavior? The case of Black Lives Matter and policing

q5.value: Thanks to Adelaide Oh and Cayla Barry for invaluable research assistance.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Does protest work? A rich literature has sought to measure protest’s long-run effectiveness in changing legislative outcomes (Gillion, 2012; Gause, 2016), policy (Andrews, 1997; Biggs and Andrews, 2015), and public opinion (Giugni, 1998; Huff and Kruszewska, 2016; Wasow, 2016; Enos, Kaufman and Sands, 2017). In this project, we seek to answer a shorter-term question: do protests directly change the behavior of street-level bureaucrats? Even before elected officials change laws and policies, do non-elected bureaucrats respond to protesters’ demands? In this study, we focus on a particular type of street-level bureaucrats (police) and ask how their behavior changed after a particular set of protests (the Black Lives Matter protests that swept across the US in December 2014). We seek to test whether police behavior changed in the wake of local Black Lives Matter (BLM) protests. Specifically, we ask whether police became less likely to make discretionary arrests for minor crimes, which would align with protesters’ demands, or whether they exhibited a “backlash” response to protests and made more of these arrests. We also collect data on police killings of civilians, and on crime clearance rates, as discussed below. This research will yield a new understanding of both the impact of protest, and the behavior of street-level bureaucrats. If we find that police change their behavior to accord with protesters’ concerns, this would suggest that protests can be effective in previously- unmeasured ways. If they do not react to protests, or if they instead show evidence of backlash, this would provide a cautionary tale to activists. It would also differentiate police from other unelected officials that have been shown to move with various measures of public opinion, such as judges (Giles, Blackstone and Vining, 2008) and social service workers (Weissert, 1994; Schram, College and Fording, 2007).

q16.value: We want to know whether police departments change their behavior after Black Lives Matter protests take place, particularly in the first few months after the protest (before there has been time for legislative responses and policy change). We can imagine three different patterns of response from police departments (described in more detail in the pre-analysis plan): responsiveness, in which they make fewer discretionary arrests and possibly kill fewer civilians; backlash, in which they make more discretionary arrests and possibly kill more civilians; and work slowdown, in which they make fewer discretionary arrests and kill fewer civilians, but may also show reduced violent crime clearance. So in essence we are testing three composite hypotheses: police show a pattern of responsiveness to protest, police show a pattern of backlash in response to protest, or police show a pattern of work stoppage in response to protest. We will first run separate tests for each outcome variable (minor arrests, police killings of civilians, violent crime clearance rates) to see whether protests increase or decrease it, correcting for multiple testing. Then we plan to use the NPC package in R (provided we're able to adapt it to our analysis) to test the composite hypotheses described in the prior paragraph.

q17.value: We will use a difference-in-differences design, comparing policing over time in cities that did and did not experience Black Lives Matter protests during December 2014 (after the non-indictment of the officer who killed Eric Garner). We will use monthly municipality-level data on our three main outcome measures: minor/discretionary arrests, police killings of civilians, and violent crime clearance rates. (We also discuss several other possible outcome measures in the attached pre-analysis plan, in case we are able to collect enough data to use them: 911 response times, vehicle stops, and civil forfeitures.)

q19.value: (not sure yet, but we're trying to collect the full set of cities over 30,000 population)

attributes.title: The Two Dimensions of Social Inclusion: Testing Optimal Distinctiveness Theory in Six Experiments
attributes.description: Brewer’s (1991) Optimal Distinctiveness Theory (ODT) suggests a two-dimensional model of inclusion (See Figure 1). She argues that for an individual to identify with a group, the individual does not only need to assimilate with the group members, but simultaneously satisfy differentiation needs. In this set of six studies, we test this assumption by comparing how the four cells of ODT predict identification with superordinate and in-group (i.e., subgroup, subordinate) identities and well-being. These mediations have been suggested by the Rejection-Identification Model (RIM; Branscombe, Schmitt, & Harvey, 1999), the Rejection-Disidentification Model (Jasinskaja-Lahti, Liebkind, & Solheim, 2009), and the Inclusion-Identification Model (IIM; Adams et al., in prep.). Note that we do not test these mediations in the six students pre-registered here. We only compare how the conditions affect identities and well-being, respectively. Mediation will be assessed in follow-up projects.
